We may do good by personal exertion (XIX. 65), to the state or to individuale. One may often gain much influence and popularity by aiding others with advice3 and for this reason the study of law was formerly held in great honor. When this is beyond our power, we can give our eloquence (66) or our influence (67) in their behalf, taking care, how- ever (68), not to offend others·

In helping others (XX. 69, 70) it is generally recognized that wc ought to consider the character rather than the posi- tion of the person3 but we are very much prone to the eon- trary. And yet the poor honest inan will always cher-ish gratitude for a benefit, while the rich man will consider your service to him as an interested action. Finally, benefits conferred on the state (XXI. 72) may af- fect the whole body of citizens, or individuale. We may aim to accomplish both ends; but in benefiting individuals we must do no harm to the community. A public official (73) should not infringe on the rights of property, should avoid levying con- tributione (74), if possible, by providing resources beforehand, and never abuse his trust (75) for his own personal advan- tage. This last has now become common, but (XXII. 76) was not formerly s0, aS‚ for instance, with Scipio, P. Aemilius, L. Mummius. Those who pass agrarian laws (78) or laws for cancelling debts disturb the harmony of the citizens and offend against justice itself; moreover‚ they do not attain their end (79).
